I had bilateral or synchronous breast cancer at 45 that is highly ER +... and that was 4 years after having ovaries removed. I tested negative for all BRCA, etc. Then why did I get it? Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2012 09:43PM Beckers wrote: Trinity, I felt pressured for bilat lumpectomy + rads. The goal for the cancer center i went to is breast conservation. They told me statistically, the outcome would be the same for both, except I understand local recurrence rate is higher with lumpectomy. I also had to consider radiation could affect my skin adversely making future reconstruction difficult should that recurrence happen down the road. I'm grateful for honesty of RO about risks given I have bilat BC, so I made difficult choice for BMX. Thankful that I have options. It is definitely a personal choice with a lot to consider. For me, surgery and anti-hormonal meds was the lesser of the evils. My oncotype score is only 19 so no chemo. But, having quite an invasive surgery and reconstructive process that is also dangerous. That is why you see that I've already had lumpectomies and now BMX scheduled.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2013 10:05PM Beckers wrote: Virginia, My tumor did not hurt. I would not have known it was there if not for the mammogram. Skin was not red. Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2015 04:09PM Beckers wrote: Hi Sherrie. Welcome to the club no one wants to be a part of. However, you will find great support on these boards. I found the thread of women who had surgery the same month and that group of women carried each other through. Also there is a thread to help prepare you for surgery I found helpful. I personally had bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. The type of surgery you choose is a very personal choice. Not everyone can tolerate the loss of both breasts well. For some of us, it was not as big of a deal. I had lumpectomies initially at the pressure of the surgery center but was confident I wanted bilateral mastectomy from the start. (Everyone has individual sets of circumstances.) But....that is not a guarantee you won't have a recurrence. There is no point beating yourself up for the procrastination. Thank God it is not a high grade. It's a vast world here and feels like it takes over your life, but you will get through it. Hang in there

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2013 12:11AM Beckers wrote: Sweet tea, the idea of breast cancer is frightening, but there are many other things it could be as well. The waiting game is one of the hardest things to live with around here. Unfortunately, there is no way around it. This site is the best place to find information and make friendships with others in the same boat! I know it's scary. It's so good that you do check your breasts often. Mammogram found my breast cancer. I didn't even know what my breasts usually felt like and I know I never would have found it. Like fredntan said, this is a good time for reality check and you can make and learn about prevention and any life changes that may be needed. I had no ovaries, no family history and still grew bilateral breast cancers in my 40's that were highly estrogen positive. Well....I learned that my belly fat or hormones in meats or styrofoam and plastics are other sources of estrogen. Lots you can be learning about. Praying for B9 results for you. Try to relax as you wait.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2013 09:03PM Beckers wrote: This brings back memories as I was caring for my dying father last year when I found out I had possible breast cancer. I went to City of Hope which is a cancer center and they wanted surgery scheduled within 6 weeks from time lump was discovered (mammogram in my case). I know of others who have Kaiser and are happy with their care. I would just be the squeaky wheel and call member services, doctor, surgery, whoever you can and tell them you need appointment sooner than one month. What you are going through is so difficult....almost imaginable. As far as the odds. Well, hard to say but I have been told approx 80% are benign. If you had mammogram, the radiologist assigns a BIRAD #, which is an indication of the likelihood of malignancy. With respect to stress, poor eating habits, etc. There are some good articles on this site about those topics. I would browse around. Good luck to you. My heart goes out to you and your Mom. Wishing you B9 results.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2012 09:47PM Beckers wrote: Hi Trina, I was scheduled for DIEP reconstruction, which is where they use tummy flaps. They ended up having to take a small bit of muscle so I believe what I actually had was a free TRAM. It is a difficult recovery for sure but I have no regrets. I woke up with nice warm breasts :o). They are just now feeling like they belong to me...ha. I had to get used to them. You lose the feeling in your breasts and that is very strange. I didn't do it for the tummy tuck but that was an added plus as I had big babies and 4 abdominal surgeries previously. Now I have a smooth tummy. Swollen, sore and a very large scar from one side of my body to the other but my PS made it at the csection level, which is nice.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2013 02:19AM Beckers wrote: In denial, I think everything you said crossed my mind too. Ha! Yes, they usually do try to do surgery within a certain timeframe. For me, I got a call on Friday to come Monday for pre op and I could have lumpectomies on Tues or mastectomies on Wed (I had it in both breasts). I too had pain after biopsy. I think we just have to learn to live with wondering about all of the other aches and pains. I've even considered writing down how I feel in every part of my body so I have a baseline. In the beginning, my father passed away and I could not fathom inflicting pain on my family so my initial plan was to keep it secret. I don't know if that was realistic though to be honest. Therapist is a great idea! Also, ask the doctor about anti anxiety meds if you think that will help you sleep for sure. Doesn't hurt. I take melatonin now. My dietician said a study finds it even beneficial for breast cancer. See...I have thought about or experienced a lot of what you have. What I love about this site!!!
